Accurate and Fast Federated Learning
via IID and Communication-Aware Grouping

Jin-woo Lee â€ƒâ€ƒ Jaehoon Oh â€ƒâ€ƒ Yooju Shin â€ƒâ€ƒ Jae-Gil Lee â€ƒâ€ƒ Se-Young Yoon
Abstract

Federated learning has emerged as a new paradigm of collaborative machine learning; however, it has also faced several challenges such as non-independent and identically distributedâ€‰(IID) data and high communication cost. To this end, we propose a novel framework of IID and communication-aware group federated learning that simultaneously maximizes both accuracy and communication speed by grouping nodes based on data distributions and physical locations of the nodes. Furthermore, we provide a formal convergence analysis and an efficient optimization algorithm called FedAvg-IC. Experimental results show that, compared with the state-of-the-art algorithms, FedAvg-IC improved the test accuracy by up to 22.2%percent22.222.2\% and simultaneously reduced the communication time to as small as 12%percent1212\%.

Machine Learning, ICML

1 Introduction

Federated learningâ€‰(KonecnÃ½ etÂ al., 2016a; McMahan etÂ al., 2017) enables mobile devices to collaboratively learn a shared model while keeping all training data on the devices, thus avoiding transferring data to the cloud or central server. In this framework, a local model is updated using the data on each device, and all local updates are periodically aggregated to the global model; then, each local model is synchronized with the global model. Federated learning is attracting more attention, as indicated by the recent release of TensorFlow Federatedâ€‰(TFF) in March 2019â€‰(Google, 2019). One of the main reasons for this recent boom in federated learning is that it does not compromise user privacy. However, there are several challenges despite federated learningâ€™s growing popularity. McMahan etÂ al. (2017) pointed out that federated learning has three unique properties: non-independent and identically distributedâ€‰(IID), unbalanced, and massively-distributed. In this study, we tackle the challenges for the non-IID and massively-distributed properties as follows:

  • â€¢

    Non-IID Challenge: Because each mobile device typically stores the data generated by a particular user, each local data distribution does not represent the global population distribution. This non-IID property definitely hinders the convergence of federated learning and degrades prediction accuracy.

  • â€¢

    Limited Communication Challenge: Because several thousands of devices typically participate in federated learning, the training process is massively distributed, thus causing a huge burden on the backboneâ€‰(wireless) networkâ€‰(Park etÂ al., 2018).

To the best of our knowledge, no existing work has addressed both of the above challenges simultaneously. However, there have been active studies on each challenge. Notably, Lin etÂ al. (2018) proposed a group-based learning algorithm, where the nodesâ€‰(i.e., devices) are grouped into node groups; the local models are first aggregated to a group model, and the group models are then aggregated to the global model. While the group-based learning relieves the non-IID issue, it may cause high communication overheads especially if far-away nodes belong to the same node group. Wang etÂ al. (2019) proposed a resource-constrained optimization algorithm to optimize the number of communication rounds but did not address the non-IID issue. In contrast, Zhao etÂ al. (2018) proposed a data sharing strategy that distributes a small subset of global data to all nodes for resolving the non-IIDness, but the additional global communication cost is not seriously considered and it somewhat violates the philosophy of federated learning.

In this paper, we propose a novel framework of IID and communication-aware group federated learning to address both challenges. Here, nodes are grouped by the IID and communication-aware grouping principle to make the data distribution of each group closer to the global IID data distribution and to reduce node-to-group communication simultaneously. Fig.Â 1, where the data distributions are distinguished by their different shapes, illustrates the proposed framework as well as two simple alternatives. Communication-aware grouping concentrates on the limited communication challenge at the cost of accuracy, and IID grouping concentrates on the non-IID challenge at the cost of efficiency. On the other hand, our proposed framework aims at presenting a hybrid of the two extreme cases. Overall, the key contributions are summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    Problem Formulationâ€‰(Section 3): We formulate the problem as a bi-objective optimization that determines node groups by considering the difference in data distribution for the local-to-group and group-to-global levels as well as the communication delay based on the physical locations of nodes.

  • â€¢

    Convergence Analysisâ€‰(Section 4): We formally derive the convergence bound of group federated learning. As per our analysis, the optimal node grouping is achieved when the difference in data distribution for the group-to-global level and the group communication delay are simultaneously minimized.

  • â€¢

    Optimization Algorithmâ€‰(Section 5): We design a control algorithm, called FedAvg-IC, to find the near-optimal node grouping that minimizes both IID and communication costs.

  • â€¢

    High Performanceâ€‰(Section 6): We empirically compared FedAvg-IC with three federated learning algorithms on four benchmark datasets. FedAvg-IC reached a higher accuracy by up to 22.2%percent22.222.2\% and simultaneously reduced communication time to as small as 12%percent1212\%, compared with the three selected algorithms.

2 Preliminaries and Related Work

In this section, we first briefly describe federated learning and then survey relevant studies that handle either non-IIDness or limited communication.

2.2.2 Global-Information Sharing

Sharing global information is effective in mitigating the non-IIDness of a local node. The most common approach is to share a subset of global IID data samples to make the local data distribution closer to the population data distributionâ€‰(Zhao etÂ al., 2018; Yoshida etÂ al., 2019). FSVRGâ€‰(KonecnÃ½ etÂ al., 2016a) shares a subset of global data features to scale up the feature-related parameters of a local optimizer. FAugâ€‰(Jeong etÂ al., 2018) shares a generative model that can produce an augmented IID dataset.

2.3 Related Work on the Communication Challenge

2.3.1 Communication-Aware Learning

AdaptiveFLâ€‰(Wang etÂ al., 2019) extends FedAvg to adaptively optimize the number of global aggregations by considering resource consumption such as communication. FedCSâ€‰(Nishio & Yonetani, 2019) minimizes the overall communication delay for a set of sampled learners by considering a round-trip time constraint. HierFAVGâ€‰(Liu etÂ al., 2019), which is the state-of-the-art approach for group federated learning, groups nodes by network edges to facilitate communication between the nodes in proximity. Similarly, we define a novel optimization problem that considers both IID and communication costs for maximizing accuracy and efficiency of federated learning, as shown in Section 3.

2.3.2 Communication Overhead Reduction

Reducing communication overheads in federated learning usually leads to saving both communication and computation resources. The overheads include the number of participating nodes and the amount of communication data. The participating nodes can be sampled by following a certain probability distributionâ€‰(McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Li etÂ al., 2019; Sahu etÂ al., 2018), but this approach is beyond the scope of this paper. Meanwhile, communication data size can be reduced by using a quantization or compression techniqueâ€‰(KonecnÃ½ etÂ al., 2016b; Sattler etÂ al., 2019) or by placing intermediate parameter servers in a network topologyâ€‰(Bonawitz etÂ al., 2019). We also attempt to reduce communication data size in Section 5.

3 IID and Communication-Aware Group Federated Learning

Our primary goal is to train a global model that simultaneously minimizes the global loss in Eq.Â (3) and the total communication delay by considering the aforementioned challenges, which can be formulated as Eq.Â (5).

4 Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we provide a theoretical analysis of the IID and communication-aware group federated learning. Based on an assumption and definitions in Section 4.1, we analyze the convergence of group federated learning in Section 4.2 and draw notable remarks for the main problem in Section 4.3. TableÂ 1 summarizes the notation used in this paper.

4.1 Assumption and Definitions

We make the following assumption for the loss function Fiksubscriptsuperscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘–F^{k}_{i}, as in many other relevant studiesâ€‰(Liu etÂ al., 2019; Wang etÂ al., 2019). For every iğ‘–i and kğ‘˜k, Fiksubscriptsuperscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘–F^{k}_{i} is convex111We will empirically show that a non-convex function works well in Section 6.; Fiksubscriptsuperscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘–F^{k}_{i} is ÏğœŒ\rho-Lipschitz, i.e., âˆ¥Fikâ€‹(w)âˆ’Fikâ€‹(wâ€²)âˆ¥â‰¤Ïâ€‹âˆ¥wâˆ’wâ€²âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptsuperscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘–wsubscriptsuperscriptFkisuperscriptwâ€²ğœŒdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥wsuperscriptwâ€²\left\lVert F^{k}_{i}({\textbf{w}})-F^{k}_{i}({\textbf{w}}^{\prime})\right\rVert\leq\rho\left\lVert{\textbf{w}}-{\textbf{w}}^{\prime}\right\rVert for any w and wâ€²superscriptwâ€²{\textbf{w}}^{\prime}; and Fiksubscriptsuperscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘–F^{k}_{i} is Î²ğ›½\beta-smooth, i.e., âˆ¥âˆ‡Fikâ€‹(w)âˆ’âˆ‡Fikâ€‹(wâ€²)âˆ¥â‰¤Î²â€‹âˆ¥wâˆ’wâ€²âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡subscriptsuperscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘–wâˆ‡subscriptsuperscriptFkisuperscriptwâ€²ğ›½delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥wsuperscriptwâ€²\left\lVert\nabla F^{k}_{i}({\textbf{w}})-\nabla F^{k}_{i}({\textbf{w}}^{\prime})\right\rVert\leq\beta\left\lVert{\textbf{w}}-{\textbf{w}}^{\prime}\right\rVert for any w and wâ€²superscriptwâ€²{\textbf{w}}^{\prime}.

Under this assumption, LemmaÂ 1 holds for the group and global loss functions.

Lemma 1.

Fğ¹F and Fksuperscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F^{k} are convex, ÏğœŒ\rho-Lipschitz, and Î²ğ›½\beta-smooth.

Proof.

It is straightforward from the aforementioned assumption and the definitions of Fğ¹F and Fksuperscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F^{k} in Eq.Â (3). âˆ

Definition 2 (Group-Based Gradient Divergence).

Given a certain group membership z, for any iğ‘–i, kğ‘˜k, and w, Î´iksubscriptsuperscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜ğ‘–\delta^{k}_{i} is defined as the gradient difference between the iğ‘–i-th local loss and the kğ‘˜k-th group loss; Î”ksuperscriptÎ”ğ‘˜\Delta^{k} is defined as the gradient difference between the kğ‘˜k-th group loss and the global loss, which can be expressed as Eq.Â (7).

Then, the local-to-group divergence Î´ğ›¿\delta and the group-to-global divergence Î”Î”\Delta are formulated as Eq.Â (8).

4.3 Theoretical Analysis for the Main Problem

Based on the convergence analysis, we interpret the IID and communication-aware group federated learning as follows.

Remark 1 (Dominance of Î”Î”\Delta).

The IID objectiveâ€‰(minâ¡Fâ€‹(wâ€‹(T))ğ¹wT\min{F({\textbf{w}}(T))}) in Eq.Â (5) is the same as minimizing Fâ€‹(wâ€‹(T))âˆ’Fâ€‹(wâˆ—)ğ¹wTFsuperscriptwF({\textbf{w}}(T))-F({\textbf{w}}^{*}) in Eq.Â (9) because Fâ€‹(wâˆ—)ğ¹superscriptwF({\textbf{w}}^{*}) is a constant. Thus, given Ï„1subscriptÏ„1\uptau_{1}, Ï„2subscriptÏ„2\uptau_{2}, and |ğ’¦|ğ’¦\left\lvert\mathcal{K}\right\rvert, because Î”Î”\Delta is the most dominant factor in Eq.Â (9), it is important for the IID objective to reduce Î”Î”\Delta by changing z.

Remark 2 (Dominance of dgâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹psubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘d_{group}).

For the communication objectiveâ€‰(minâ¡dgâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹pâ€‹(Ï„2âˆ’1)+dgâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹bâ€‹aâ€‹lsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘subscriptÏ„21subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™\min{d_{group}\left\lparen\uptau_{2}-1\right\rparen+d_{global}}), because dgâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹bâ€‹aâ€‹lsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™d_{global} is not affected by a certain node grouping from the definition of global aggregation in Eq.Â (4), given Ï„1subscriptÏ„1\uptau_{1}, Ï„2subscriptÏ„2\uptau_{2}, and |ğ’¦|ğ’¦\left\lvert\mathcal{K}\right\rvert, it is important for the communication objective to reduce dgâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹psubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘d_{group} by changing z.

In conclusion, we establish the IID and communication-aware grouping principle: a group federated learning algorithm should group nodes by simultaneously minimizing Î”Î”\Delta and dgâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹psubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘d_{group} to maximize both accuracy and efficiency.

5 Optimization Algorithm: FedAvg-IC

To solve Eq.Â (5), an efficient heuristic algorithm is essential because the grouping problem itself is NP-Hard with the complexity of Oâ€‹(|ğ’©||ğ’¦|)ğ‘‚superscriptğ’©ğ’¦O(\left\lvert\mathcal{N}\right\rvert^{\left\lvert\mathcal{K}\right\rvert}). In this regard, we propose a novel algorithm called FedAvg-ICâ€‰(Federated Averaging with IID and Communication-Aware Grouping).

5.1 Algorithm Description

FedAvg-IC aims at quickly finding an accurate global model based on the near-optimal node grouping that follows the IID and communication-aware grouping principle, for which we adopt the k-medoids algorithmâ€‰(Park & Jun, 2009). The node grouping involves assigning each node to the closest medoid node and updating a representative medoid node for each group. Here, the distance is measured by the cost functions defined as follows.

Assign Cost: To evaluate the cost of assigning the iğ‘–i-th node to the kğ‘˜k-th group, we model the IID costâ€‰(CostA,iâ€‹iâ€‹dsubscriptCostğ´ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘\textsc{Cost}_{A,iid}) and communication costâ€‰(CostA,câ€‹oâ€‹mâ€‹msubscriptCostğ´ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘š\textsc{Cost}_{A,comm}) using Î”ksuperscriptÎ”ğ‘˜\Delta^{k} in Eq.Â (7) and the hop distance between the iğ‘–i-th node and iksubscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜i_{k}-th medoid node, respectively, as shown in Eq.Â (10).

CostA,iâ€‹iâ€‹dâ€‹(i,k)â‰œÎ”kwhereiâˆˆğ’©kCostA,câ€‹oâ€‹mâ€‹mâ€‹(i,k)â‰œHopDistanceâ€‹(i,ik)missing-subexpressionformulae-sequenceâ‰œsubscriptCostğ´ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘˜superscriptÎ”ğ‘˜whereisuperscriptğ’©kmissing-subexpressionâ‰œsubscriptCostğ´ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘˜HopDistanceğ‘–subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜\begin{aligned} &\textsc{Cost}_{A,iid}\left\lparen i,k\right\rparen\triangleq\Delta^{k}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ {\text{where}}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ i\in\mathcal{N}^{k}\\ &\textsc{Cost}_{A,comm}\left\lparen i,k\right\rparen\triangleq\textsc{HopDistance}\left\lparen i,i_{k}\right\rparen\end{aligned}

 (10)

Update Cost: To evaluate the cost of selecting the iğ‘–i-th node in the kğ‘˜k-th group as a new medoid for the group, we model the IID costâ€‰(CostU,iâ€‹iâ€‹dsubscriptCostğ‘ˆğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘\textsc{Cost}_{U,iid}) and the communication costâ€‰(CostU,câ€‹oâ€‹mâ€‹msubscriptCostğ‘ˆğ‘ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘š\textsc{Cost}_{U,comm}) by the local-to-global divergence of the iğ‘–i-th node and the sum of hop distances to all other nodes in the group, respectively, as shown in Eq.Â (11).

CostU,iâ€‹iâ€‹dâ€‹(i,k)â‰œ|ğ’Ÿik||ğ’Ÿ|â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡Fikâ€‹(w)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(w)âˆ¥CostU,câ€‹oâ€‹mâ€‹mâ€‹(i,k)â‰œâˆ‘jâˆˆğ’©kHopDistanceâ€‹(i,j)missing-subexpressionâ‰œsubscriptCostğ‘ˆğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ’Ÿdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡subscriptsuperscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘–wâˆ‡ğ¹wmissing-subexpressionâ‰œsubscriptCostğ‘ˆğ‘ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘—superscriptğ’©ğ‘˜HopDistanceğ‘–ğ‘—\begin{aligned} &\textsc{Cost}_{U,iid}\left\lparen i,k\right\rparen\triangleq\leavevmode\nobreak\ \frac{\left\lvert\mathcal{D}^{k}_{i}\right\rvert}{\left\lvert\mathcal{D}\right\rvert}\left\lVert\nabla F^{k}_{i}\left\lparen{\textbf{w}}\right\rparen-\nabla F\left\lparen{\textbf{w}}\right\rparen\right\rVert\\ &\textsc{Cost}_{U,comm}\left\lparen i,k\right\rparen\triangleq\leavevmode\nobreak\ \sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}^{k}}{\textsc{HopDistance}\left\lparen i,j\right\rparen}\end{aligned}

 (11)

Combined Cost: Given Xâˆˆ{A,U}ğ‘‹ğ´ğ‘ˆX\in\left\{A,U\right\}, CostX,iâ€‹iâ€‹dsubscriptCostğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘\textsc{Cost}_{X,iid}â€‰(IID cost) and CostX,câ€‹oâ€‹mâ€‹msubscriptCostğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘š\textsc{Cost}_{X,comm}â€‰(communication cost) are combined into a single cost, as shown in Eq.Â (12).

CostXâ‰œÎ±iâ€‹iâ€‹dâ€‹CostX,iâ€‹iâ€‹dCX,iâ€‹iâ€‹d+Î±câ€‹oâ€‹mâ€‹mâ€‹CostX,câ€‹oâ€‹mâ€‹mCX,câ€‹oâ€‹mâ€‹mâ‰œsubscriptCostğ‘‹subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptCostğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptğ¶ğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptğ›¼ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘šsubscriptCostğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘šsubscriptğ¶ğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘š\textsc{Cost}_{X}\triangleq\alpha_{iid}\frac{\textsc{Cost}_{X,iid}}{C_{X,iid}}+\alpha_{comm}\frac{\textsc{Cost}_{X,comm}}{C_{X,comm}}

Î±ğ›¼\alpha is the weight, and Cğ¶C is the normalizing constant222Cğ¶C is set to be the first cost value in the optimization processâ€‰(Grodzevich & Romanko, 2006)..

Algorithm 1 shows the overall procedure of FedAvg-IC. It takes the set of node indices ğ’©ğ’©\mathcal{N}, the final time Tğ‘‡T, the learning steps Ï„10subscriptsuperscriptÏ„01\uptau^{0}_{1} and Ï„20subscriptsuperscriptÏ„02\uptau^{0}_{2}, and the number of node groups |ğ’¦|ğ’¦\left\lvert\mathcal{K}\right\rvert as the input and returns the final global model wâ€‹(T)wT{\textbf{w}}\left\lparen T\right\rparen as the output. It begins by initializing the global model and group membership randomlyâ€‰(Line 1). Then, the global model is broadcast to all nodesâ€‰(Line 2). Then, the local update is performed at each nodeâ€‰(Lines 4â€“5); each group model is learned by aggregating all local models in the group and then broadcast back to all nodesâ€‰(Lines 6â€“9); the global model is learned by aggregating all local models and then broadcast back to all nodesâ€‰(Lines 10â€“12). After the first global aggregation, the group membership z is updatedâ€‰(Line 14). Overall, Lines 3â€“15 repeat for Tğ‘‡T steps.

The Node_Grouping function attempts to find a group membership z that reduces the combined cost in Eq.Â (12) to the extent possible. For this purpose, it begins by selecting random medoid nodes ğ’©msubscriptğ’©ğ‘š\mathcal{N}_{m} of size |ğ’¦|ğ’¦\left\lvert\mathcal{K}\right\rvert. Then, it iteratively updates z by minimizing CostAsubscriptCostğ´\textsc{Cost}_{A} in Eq.Â (10) for all nodes and CostUsubscriptCostğ‘ˆ\textsc{Cost}_{U} in Eq.Â (11) for all groups until the cost is steadyâ€‰(Lines 19â€“21).

6 Evaluation

6.1 Experimental Setting

Configuration: We developed a federated learning simulator to extensively evaluate the performance of various algorithms, models, datasets, and networks based on TensorFlow 1.14.0. Please refer to AppendixÂ C.1 for details.

Algorithms: We compared the following three algorithms.

  • â€¢

    FedAvgâ€‰(McMahan etÂ al., 2017), which is used as a baseline, does not consider node grouping at all.

  • â€¢

    HierFAVGâ€‰(Liu etÂ al., 2019) groups nodes by network edges to facilitate communication between nodes.

  • â€¢

    FedAvg-IC groups nodes by minimizing both IID and communication costs. We also considered FedAvg-IC that only minimizes either IID or communication cost as FedAvg-I or FedAvg-C, respectively.

Datasets: We used four datasets, MNIST-Oâ€‰(LeCun etÂ al., 1998), MNIST-Fâ€‰(Xiao etÂ al., 2017), FEMNISTâ€‰(Caldas etÂ al., 2018), and CelebAâ€‰(Liu etÂ al., 2015), which consist of 70,000, 70,000, 78,353, and 10,014 examples, respectively. The ratio of train/validation/test examples was 3:1:1, as suggested by Caldas etÂ al. (2018).

Data Distribution: To simulate a wide range of non-IIDness, we designed six cases of class diversity on each node and edge, as shown in TableÂ 2. For example, in the Dtq setting, only a tenth of the classes can exist per node, and a quarter of the classes can exist per edge.

Models: We used three training models, the softmax regressionâ€‰(SR), the 2 layered perceptron neural networkâ€‰(2NN), and the convolutional neural networkâ€‰(CNN). Please refer to AppendixÂ C.1 for details.

Methodology: Deterministic gradient descentâ€‰(DGD) was used for the SR to solve convex problems, and stochastic gradient descentâ€‰(SGD) was used for the 2NN and the CNN to solve non-convex problems. We evaluate each algorithm five times and report the average with standard deviation.

6.2 Accuracy Results

Fig.Â 4 and Fig.Â 4 show the test accuracy of three federated learning algorithms on a non-IIDâ€‰(Dtt) dataset according to the elapsed time and epoch, respectively. Overall, FedAvg-IC outperformed FedAvg by up to 17.4% (Fig.Â 4) and HierFAVG by up to 22.2% (Fig.Â 4). In Fig.Â 4, the algorithms that considered communication such as FedAvg-IC and FedAvg-C outperformed the others. The higher accuracy of FedAvg-IC is attributed to a decreased Î”Î”\Delta in the IID cost in Eq.Â (12). Please refer to AppendixÂ C.2 for details.

6.3 Efficiency Results

TableÂ 3 shows the elapsed time and speedup on the most non-IIDâ€‰(Dtt) and IIDâ€‰(Dhh) datasets. In terms of the elapsed time, FedAvg-IC outperformed FedAvg and HierFAVG by up to 8.3 times and 4.8 times, respectively. Even though HierFAVG is in favor of communication efficiency, because the edge-based learning of HierFAVG degrades the accuracy in non-IID settings, it did not reach the target accuracy for the 2NN and the CNN. The faster convergence speed of FedAvg-IC is attributed to a decreased dgâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹psubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘d_{group} in Eq.Â (12) as well as a decreased communication data size by the combined aggregation. Please refer to AppendixÂ C.2.

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we proposed a novel framework of IID and communication-aware group federated learning to address both the non-IID and limited communication challenges simultaneously. Our formal convergence analysis led to the IID and communication-aware grouping principle that is incorporated into our optimization algorithm FedAvg-IC. Extensive experiments were performed using our own federated learning simulator, and the results demonstrated that FedAvg-IC outperformed HierFAVG by up to 22.2%percent22.222.2\% in terms of test accuracy and FedAvg by up to 8.38.38.3 times in terms of convergence speed. Overall, we believe that our framework has made important steps towards accurate and fast federated learning.

Appendix B Advanced Implementation Technique

In addition, we propose a novel combined aggregation technique that reduces the size of communication data in FedAvg-IC. Fig.Â 5 represents an example of the combined aggregation. It is obvious that communication cost is almost negligible within an edge, and a group may consist of a few edges. Then, a certain local aggregation serverâ€‰(solid squares) can locally aggregateâ€‰(dashed arrows) local modelsâ€‰(hollow squares) in the same edge and sendâ€‰(solid arrows) the locally aggregated model to the group or global aggregation serverâ€‰(solid circles) with reduced communication data. This technique can be applied to both group and global aggregations as well as both group and global broadcasts inversely. We also note that this technique is similar to the partial aggregation of Dryadâ€‰(Isard etÂ al., 2007) and the combiner of MapReduceâ€‰(Dean & Ghemawat, 2008).

Appendix C Supplementary Evaluation Material

C.1 Experimental Setting Details

Configuration: We developed a federated learning simulator to extensively evaluate the performance of various algorithms, models, datasets, and networks. We used TensorFlow 1.14.0 to implement federated learning444TensorFlow Federatedâ€‰(Google, 2019) does not fully support the parallelism level of this simulation yet. and ns-3 3.30 to simulate the network on servers with Intel Core i7-6700 and NVIDIA TITAN X. For reproducibility, we provide the source code at https://bit.ly/39g10Ip.

Models: We used following three training models.

  • â€¢

    The softmax regressionâ€‰(SR) involved 7,850 parameters.

  • â€¢

    The 2 layered perceptron neural networkâ€‰(2NN) contained two hidden layers each with 200 units and ReLU activiation; it contained 199,210 parameters.

  • â€¢

    The convolutional neural networkâ€‰(CNN) contained two 5Ã—\times5 convolutional layers with 64 channels, each followed by 2Ã—\times2 max pooling and local response normalization. After the two convolutional layers, a fully-connected layer with 256 units and ReLU activation was added; the output layer with softmax activation was added. The CNN contained 369,098 parameters. For CelebA, the benchmark CNN, provided by Caldas etÂ al. (2018), was used, and it contained 124,808 parameters.

Metrics: We evaluated the performance of the algorithms using the following metrics. The test accuracy was measured to evaluate the training progress and the predictive accuracy, respectively. In addition, the epoch and the time taken to reach a target test accuracy were measured to evaluate the convergence speed.

Hyperparameters: TableÂ 4 lists the hyperparameters used for the model and the algorithm.

  • â€¢

    Model: We searched the best batch size and learning rate for each model as follows. For the SR, 2NN and CNN models, the batch size was varied from 323232 to 512512512 with an increment rate of 222, and the learning rateâ€‰(Î·ğœ‚\eta) was varied from 10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3} to 103superscript10310^{3} with an increment rate of 101010. For the CNN model used for the CelebA dataset, the batch size was set to 555, and the learning rate was set to 0.0010.0010.001, as suggested by Caldas etÂ al. (2018).

  • â€¢

    Algorithm: FedAvg takes a single learning stepâ€‰(Ï„Ï„\uptau) as its input, whereas HierFAVG and FedAvg-IC take two learning stepsâ€‰(Ï„1subscriptÏ„1\uptau_{1} and Ï„2subscriptÏ„2\uptau_{2}). To solely focus on the effects of communication, the product of all the learning steps of each algorithm was determined to be 555, which was one of the suggested values by McMahan etÂ al. (2017). In FedAvg-IC, the number of groups |ğ’¦|ğ’¦\left\lvert\mathcal{K}\right\rvert was varied in the range of [2,5,10,15,20,30]2510152030\left[2,5,10,15,20,30\right]555A sophisticated heuristic for determining the number of groups is an important issue in group federated learning, and we leave it as future work.. We also note that, in Algorithm 1, the k-Medoid_Grouping was performed only once at the beginningâ€‰(Line 14), and the number of maximum steady steps was set to 111â€‰(Line 19), which exhibited sufficiently high accuracy for the most of experiments despite the decreased optimization opportunities.

  • â€¢

    Environment: We determined the default environment parameters by adopting commonly used ones in the previous studiesâ€‰(McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Liu etÂ al., 2019; Wang etÂ al., 2019; Caldas etÂ al., 2018).

In addition, to incorporate the unbalanced propertyâ€‰(McMahan etÂ al., 2017), the number of classes per node or edge and the number of data examples per node were randomly sampled from the normal distribution.

C.2 Evaluation Details

The higher accuracy of FedAvg-IC in Section 6.2 is attributed to a decreased Î”Î”\Delta in the IID cost in Eq.Â (12). As shown in Fig.Â 7 for the CNN on MNIST-Fâ€‰(Fig.Â 4) with the Dtt setting, FedAvg-IC significantly decreased the CostA,iâ€‹iâ€‹dsubscriptCostğ´ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘\textsc{Cost}_{A,iid} that models Î”Î”\Delta. This conforms to Remark 1.

The faster convergence speed of FedAvg-IC in Section 6.3 is attributed to a decreased dgâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹psubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘d_{group} in Eq.Â (12) as well as a decreased communication data size by the combined aggregation. As shown in Fig.Â 7, FedAvg-IC significantly decreased the CostA,câ€‹oâ€‹mâ€‹msubscriptCostğ´ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘š\textsc{Cost}_{A,comm} that models dgâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹psubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘d_{group}. This is consistent with Remark 2. It should be also noted that FedAvg-IC finds a set of Pareto optimal solutions in Fig.Â 7 whereas HierFAVG exhibits non-optimized costs. Furthermore, as shown in Fig.Â 7, the communication timeâ€”especially, for the global aggregationâ€”dropped rapidly when the combined aggregation was enabled.

C.3 Additional Results

C.3.1 Effects of Different Simulation Settings

Effects of Computation Settings: We compared different processing speedsâ€‰(5666This value is the average speed of Exynos 8895 in Samsung Galaxy S8. See https://www.anandtech.com/show/11540/samsung-galaxy-s8-exynos-versus-snapdragon/2. and 250777This value is the average speed of PowerVR GT7600, the most widely-used smartphone GPU in 2019. See https://deviceatlas.com/blog/most-used-smartphone-gpu. GFLOPS). As shown in Fig.Â 9, the results with a high processing speedâ€‰(Fig.Â 9 and 9) exhibited higher accuracy than the ones with a low processing speedâ€‰(Fig.Â 9 and 9), which is attributed to the increased number of epochs. Furthermore, we investigated the effects of different learning steps. As shown in Fig.Â 8, the results with a small number of stepsâ€‰(Fig.Â 8) exhibited higher accuracy than the ones with a large number of stepsâ€‰(Fig.Â 8), because the convergence upper bound became larger with a larger number of learning steps according to TheoremÂ 1. It should be also noted that FedAvg-IC exhibited the lowest accuracy degradation, as indicated by the arrows in Fig.Â 8; from Remark 1, when Î”Î”\Delta is sufficiently minimized, other parameters hardly influence the convergence upper bound.

Effects of Communication Settings: We compared different network typesâ€‰(fat tree and jellyfish) and link speedsâ€‰(10 and 100 MBps888These values represent the state-of-the-art mobile connection speedsâ€‰(Cisco, 2020).). As shown in Fig.Â 9, the results with the jellyfishâ€‰(dashed lines) converged faster than the ones with the fat treeâ€‰(solid lines), which is attributed to the increased throughput of the cost-efficient jellyfish networkâ€‰(Singla etÂ al., 2012). In addition, the results with a high link speedâ€‰(Fig.Â 9 and 9) converged faster than the ones with a low link speedâ€‰(Fig.Â 9 and 9), as marked by small circles in the figures with a high link speed that represent the time taken to train the same number of epochs as with a low link speed.

Effects of Data Distributions: Fig.Â 10 shows the accuracy results for different data distributions. As the variance of a distribution became higherâ€‰(Fig.Â 10 and 10), the learning curves for all algorithms became noisier. Nevertheless, FedAvg-IC still converged the fastest even with the noisier curves. We note that the mean of each data distribution does not need to be varied because, from the explanation of the data distribution in Section 6.1, it was determined to be the number of classes or data examples per node.

C.3.2 Effects of the Degree of Non-IIDness

Fig.Â 11 shows the effects of class diversityâ€‰(i.e., non-IIDness). In all cases, FedAvg-IC outperformed the state-of-the-art algorithms. When the data distribution in a node is non-IIDâ€‰(i.e., Dtt, Dtq, and Dth), FedAvg that is a node-based learning did not work well. In contrast, when the data distribution in an edge is non-IIDâ€‰(i.e., Dtt, Dtq, and Dqq), HierFAVG that is an edge-based learning did not work well. It should be noted that, because a node or an edge is very unlikely to be perfectly IID, the superiority of FedAvg-IC over the others will be valid in the real-world scenarios. Further evaluation with more realistic data distribution remains as future work.

Fig.Â 12, Fig.Â 13, and Fig.Â 14 show the accuracy results on MNIST-F, FEMNIST, and CelebA, respectively. The overall trends are shown to be similar to Fig.Â 11. The learning curves are represented with the elapsed time in the subfigures (a)â€“(c) and with the number of epochs in the subfigures (d)â€“(f). The results with the Dqq, Dqh, and Dhh settings are omitted because all curves closely overlap as before.
